ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about different forms of Islamic architecture over the past millennium and a half. The overarching question we grappled with was what actually constitutes "Islamic architecture"? Why do we classify certain buildings as Islamic architecture? Prof. Rizvi used a very expansive definition of Islamic architecture and included in the course the past several centuries of buildings in Muslim-run countries, built under the modern and post-modern conditions of colonialism, globalization, and secularization, all of which blur the distinctions between Islamic and non-Islamic architecture.
Learned more about how to engage with architecture while learning about Islamic tradition, art, and culture.
history of Islamic architecture
I learned so much about islamic architecture and architecture in general. It was a great introductory course with a broad range of interesting topics not usually covered by Western canon

I learned a lot about Islamic architecture and the ways architecture is used to convey different things. I also learned about different dynasties and eras in Islamic architecture and the Islamic world as a whole.

An introduction to Islamic architecture. The course begins with Kaaba and moves its way chronologically, focusing mostly on the middle east with a few classes looking at regions such as East or South Asia.

Knowledge of architectural traditions in several major Islamic empires of the past (and how they informed each other). Knowledge of how those past traditions in Islamic empires continue to inform architecture, and how architecture in the most recent decades/centuries in Islamic architecture has developed. To gain this understanding also learned fair amount of history (at least compared to my prior ignorance) of central and western Asia as well as Northern Africa.
Gained skills in close analysis of buildings and writing in architectural analysis and Art History more generally.
I learned about Islamic art and architecture, and the history behind it.

Learned an extensive history of Islamic architecture beginning with the Dome of the Rock and concluding with examples like the Burj Khalifa. Course primarily focused on information synthesis rather than memorization.

learned a lot about history of islamic architecture and islamic history in general, with the various dynasties and geographies. i learned how to better analyze an architectural structure and understand more about its history, impact, influence, and inspiration
I learned a lot about Islamic architecture and its progression throughout classical and modern history.
I developed such a deep understanding of and appreciation for Islamic Art and Architecture within the past and present, as well as under the greater umbrella of issues within Art History.
learned a lot about Islamic culture and architecture. Learned new vocab, buildings, and people every class

I learned of many incredible buildings, dynasties, and ways to think about expression through architecture. Skills in reading, writing, and note-taking improved.  It was helpful to be able to rewatch lectures as a study-aid.
history of art in islamic architecture
I developed a general understanding of Islamic architecture from 600 to present day. I also learned how to observe and analyze buildings and other structures, and how to write about them as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: lectures were hard to follow because images lacked labels and the slides did not have text that helped to guide what themes and points were being made. Felt like there were too many monuments covered, and not enough time spent on each one. Felt very rushed through each building, rather than pausing to discuss deeply the intricate elements of each one. Lecture felt more like it was about the history of islam rather than about the actual architecture of the course.
very good in the whole history of Islamic architecture and could be better if there would be some in depth discussion into certain topics sometimes

Overall I thought it was a good and interesting course. I would've liked a little more context and history for some of the buildings we looked at. A lot of the times it was assumed we knew or we'd just go straight into the buildings, and I would've liked to know a little more about the dynasties etc. surrounding them. I also wish more stuff was written on the slides, because often the professor would say someone's name really quickly and I'd miss it or have no idea if it was important and how to spell it. Also, maybe fewer readings. However, overall I really enjoyed this course and thought it was really interesting to learn about a lot of the things we looked at.

This course is a great way to get exposure to an interesting field that a lot of people haven't studied before. Since the class is an intro course and involves multiple writing assignments, I wish there had been more instruction on how to write about architecture, or how to build an argument around built spaces.

Strengths:
Covered a wide range of architecture which allowed us to develop a more general architectural vocabulary and history (even if this necessarily came at the expense of some depth). Even covered 20th-21st architecture, which is great as it provides you some tools to think about current buildings and projects. Assigned readings from actual academic journals, which both meant they went into greater depth which was interesting but also revealed what academic Art History looks like, which I think is useful to see in an intro class. I think the memorization format of the midterm is plus, as I am convinced that actually having to commit buildings and some major points about them to memory is pretty important for being able to draw connections and have insights when considering later material. Lectures were always clear and highlighted important context to the architecture which demonstrated how it reflected different interests or goals throughout time.

Weaknesses:
I think lectures and sections could have used a little bit more formal analysis of buildings and using that to jump off into discussions relating to context. I think this is useful first because it helps students with no experience in architecture better understand what they are looking at (and just gives them the vocabulary to do so as well), and also because it helps ground the discussion surrounding the architecture.

I really enjoyed this course. The assessments were fair and not overly long. I enjoyed the detailed descriptions of the monuments during class. One thing I would change is making the lecture outlines a word doc formatted using the built-in outline format. That way students who take notes on a service like google docs could much more easily copy and paste the outline into their own notes. Also, please write more on the slides. Images with no surrounding text make the slides basically useless when reviewing for an exam.

This course had very interesting material and I liked the combination of live section and discussion section. I wish we focused a bit more on the history and timeline/chronology of things just because we would cover such huge time periods and it was a bit confusing at time to keep everything on track
The strength of this course is that the material is easy to engage with. Sometimes the readings were a bit dense though.

Weakness: there is a lot of material covered in the first half of the semester, too much for a deep understanding.   

Strength: The Professor is engaging.  Her lectures are fast-paced but include story telling and great images.  The second half of the semester covered contemporary architecture.

strength - topic; history and architecture 
weakness - unclear direction for materials vs assignments

I liked that this course covered a wide array of times and places. I also enjoyed the lecture format and thought Professor Rizvi was a great lecturer. I would have appreciated a little more time at the end of classes for questions, but was able to ask those in discussion if there wasn't time in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The combination of recorded lecture, live virtual lecture and virtual discussion is a very good format. But I hope there would be more interactions with the instructor during the virtual lecture, not only in the discussion sessions.
I liked the split between recorded lectures and live lectures; it kept me on track but gave me a little flexibility in my schedule. I'm not sure why we did building IDs for an online midterm though.
The live lectures were nice to have to feel slightly more engaged, but they didn't provide much more than the recorded lectures.

Live lectures are superior to virtual lectures. They lend structure to the course and encourage active listening. They should be recorded and uploaded to canvas promptly after class is complete. 

Section was great. TAs were attentive and responsive, and I enjoyed being able to spend time working on gamelike activities.

My TA, Sharon Mizbani, was very good at keeping the section lively.  We did a number of exercises each section that allowed students to talk with each other and review material. 

I appreciated that one article among the readings was asterisked to indicate that we could focus on that one if we would not be able to complete all three.
sections were crucial for major grade assignments

I thought the one synchronous and one asynchronous lecture format worked well. I was very engaged in the class but was never overwhelmed by the workload and could tailor it to my own schedule. I also enjoyed the Zoom format of the discussion sections. I think there could have been a few more opportunities for participation in the lectures (ie. asking students questions, posing things to think about/discuss) but generally think everything worked very well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I loved this course so much. I happened to be already very interested in Islamic architecture before taking the course, as I have traveled to Spain and Morocco and seen examples of Islamic architecture in both countries, so this course was perfect for me. But I think anyone interested in history, art history, architecture, the Islamic world, ancient times, medieval times, early modernity/modernity/post-modernity, colonialism, and/or urban planning would like this course. It truly covers all those topics and more. Please take it if it's being offered!
yes, because it was interesting.
Definitely, it's a good introductory course if you are interested in Islamic architecture and Islamic history
I would. It's relatively specific and there's a couple papers and a midterm so it's not super easy, but it was interesting and enjoyable, and helped change the way I look at architecture.

It's an interesting introduction to the topic, but definitely be wary of its nature as a survey course. The course moves through a lot of buildings in a way that inevitably sacrifices depth for breadth. It was great to be exposed to so many cool buildings, but I often found myself wanting to spend more time on some of them, and feeling like I wasn't sure what to take away from the lecture as a whole.

Yes. An excellent course which nicely blends History and Art while still providing the tools to think about even modern day projects and how they reflect on the past. Also a pretty good course for a first exposure to architecture, as built up a vocabulary to use when analyzing and thinking about buildings, as well as providing the crucial practice in applying analysis through essays.
Yes, Profesor Rizvi is a great knowledgeable lecturer. If you are interested in the architecture the class will be interesting. If you aren't, it will not be interesting.
Yes!  Prof Rizvi is so nice and super smart, but great at explaining!
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The material is fascinating, and I feel like I learned so much.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It's engaging without being overly difficult and has very interesting content and a good instructor.
Yes i would! it is very interesting material and a really good introduction to architecture/art history for me. It's also a chill workload.
I would recommend this course to another student interested in architecture or looking to connect with their heritage.
Yes, the course was very interesting and accessible.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student. You do not have to be an Art History or Architecture major to take this class and appreciate it.
Yes.  This course was interesting and fun.  I wouldn't have come across this material in any other course or part of life.
Yes i would
yes, a great class if you are interested basic knowledge of islamic history and architecture

Yes! This class was so interesting. Professor Rizvi is an amazing teacher and I think I learned a lot of valuable information that changed the way I look at a lot of art and architecture in my daily life.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
recorded lecture and live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion
One recorded and one live lecture each week.
live discussion sections with TAs each week
There was one recorded lecture and one live virtual lecture, as well as virtual live sections.
Combination of live and recorded lectures.
Also once a week section with a TF
One recorded lecture & One live virtual lecture every week
Prerecorded lectures 1x a week in addition to the live lectures
Mixture of live virtual lectures and recorded lectures.
We had live virtual lecture along with live virtual disussion section
There were recorded lectures on Monday and live lectures on Wednesday that were then uploaded.
In addition the virtual lecture, we also had a recorded lecture for one day, and a virtual seminar.
live sections
Vitural recorded and virtual live lecture
One lecture per week was asynchronously recorded.
n/a
We had one synchronous lecture a week, one asynchronous lecture, and a discussion section on Zoom.
